title: Damage Diffusion Model in Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy
content: Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy (STEM) has had a significant progress for observing the structure of complex materials at the atomic scale. However, application of STEM for imaging beam-sensitive materials is limited due to the damage mechanisms [1, 2] – e.g., radiolysis or knock-on­ – whose overall effect on a sample is not always well-understood.
